qas.question: When the punk movement started shrinking, what began to fill the void left by their demise?

context: As the initial punk movement dwindled, <a0_0><b10_0><b14_0>vibrant new scenes<b14_0/><a0_0/> began to coalesce out of a variety of bands pursuing <a7_0>experimental sounds and <a1_0>wider conceptual<a1_0/> territory<a7_0/> in their work<b10_0/>. Many of these artists drew on <a8_0>backgrounds in <a4_0><b12_0>art<b12_0/><a8_0/><a4_0/> and viewed their music as invested in particular <a9_0>political or aesthetic agendas<a9_0/>. <a2_0><b16_0>British<b16_0/><a2_0/> music publications such as the <a6_0>NME and Sounds<a6_0/> developed an influential part in this nascent <b11_0>post-punk culture<b11_0/>, with <a3_0><b15_0>writers<b15_0/><a3_0/> like <a5_0><b13_0>Jon Savage, Paul Morley and Ian Penman<b13_0/><a5_0/> developing a dense (and often playful) style of criticism that drew on <b17_0>critical theory, radical politics and an eclectic variety of other sources<b17_0/>.
